catalog.title: FAIRmat_DFG Data Management Plan (Condensed-Matter Physics & Materials Science)
catalog.help:
This catalog provides a structured Data Management Plan (DMP) template based on the requirements of the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG). It is specifically tailored to the needs of the condensed-matter physics and materials-science community.
By using this catalog, you can ensure that your project complies with DFG guidelines while also aligning with community standards and FAIR data principles. The catalog covers key aspects of research data management, including data collection, documentation, storage, access, sharing, preservation, and reuse.
Choose this catalog when preparing a DFG proposal for single-projects or when managing research data within a project in condensed-matter physics or materials science.
If you have any questions about using this template, please contact fairmat@physik.hu-berlin.de

section.dc:comment: Before any management plan can be created, what needs to be managed should be clearly defined. In this section, provide a comprehensive description of the data that will be either generated by the proposed project or reused from another source. By doing this, researchers can ensure that they have a clear understanding of the data types and sources, allowing for effective management and organization of the data throughout the research process.
section.title: Data description

question.dc:comment: In this page, you are asked to characterize the type of research data relevant to your project. Clearly describing whether you will generate new data, reuse existing datasets, or combine both is an essential first step in the data management plan. Indicating the source and nature of your data helps clarify responsibilities, applicable standards, and later decisions on storage, sharing, and preservation.
question.help:
Research in condensed-matter physics and materials science can include:
- *Newly generated data* from experiments (e.g., spectra, images, detector signals, time series) or simulations (e.g., DFT, molecular dynamics, Monte Carlo).
- *Reuse of existing data*, such as datasets from prior projects, community repositories (e.g., NOMAD, Materials Cloud, CERN Open Data), or facility archives (e.g., synchrotron, neutron beamtime data).
- *Combined approaches*, where new data are created and complemented with existing reference or benchmark datasets.
Please select one option from the drop-down menu.
question.text: Will your project create new data, reuse existing data, or both?

option.text: The project will generate new data
The project will reuse existing data
The project will both generate new data and reuse existing data

page.title: Generated Data by the Project (1/2)
page.help:
In this section, please describe the research data that will be generated during the project. A clear description of the expected data is important for planning storage, documentation, publication, and long-term preservation.
Describe each dataset individually. For every dataset, you may include:
- *Title and short description* (what the dataset contains and how it will be produced).
- *Data type* (e.g., raw measurements, processed data, simulation results, images, spectra, time series).
- *Estimated data volume* (size per dataset and expected total).
- *File formats* (e.g., CSV, HDF5, NeXus, ROOT, NetCDF, proprietary).
- *Processing level* (raw, corrected, analyzed).
- *Special characteristics* (e.g., high-throughput data rates, large binary files, sensitive or restricted content).
You can create several datasets in this section to cover the different types of data your project will produce.

question.help: Provide a short, descriptive title (e.g., "Raw XPS spectra", "Simulation outputs – DFT band structure").

(e.g., “Raw Raman spectra of Ni-rich layered oxides collected during electrochemical cycling,” “TEM images used for defect analysis of perovskite films”)

Select the types of data that will be part of this dataset.
Typical examples in condensed-matter physics and materials science include:
- Raw measurement data (e.g., spectra, detector signals, microscopy images)
- Processed data (calibrated or noise-filtered signals, stitched images)
- Analyzed data (extracted properties, fitted models, band structures)
- Simulation inputs (initial structures, input files, parameter sets)
- Simulation outputs (trajectories, energies, wavefunctions, convergence data)
- Software or scripts (analysis pipelines, Jupyter notebooks, parsers)
- Protocols and documentation (experimental procedures, synthesis routes, workflow descriptions)
Select all that apply.

page.title: Documentation
page.help:
This page describes how your datasets will be documented and organized to ensure that they are understandable and reusable.
Each dataset should normally be described individually. If the same approach applies to several datasets (e.g., one electronic lab notebook used for all experiments, or a common file naming convention), you may provide a single answer and indicate that it covers multiple datasets.

question.help: Explain your conventions for structuring files and directories, and how you will ensure consistency across the project. Examples include date-based folder structures (YYYY-MM-DD_experimentID), systematic sample identifiers (e.g., “NiOx_sample01”), or versioning rules (v1, v2). Consistent organization helps collaborators and future users understand and find the right data.

Provide information on how your datasets will be documented so that they are understandable and reusable. Indicate which metadata standards, formats, or ontologies you will apply. Where appropriate, include general metadata (e.g., Dublin Core, DataCite), community-specific schemas (e.g., NOMAD MetaInfo, CIF, NeXus/HDF5), or domain ontologies (e.g., EMMO).
Examples: *“NOMAD Metainfo schema for simulation outputs”, “NeXus/HDF5 for beamline experiments”, “DataCite metadata when publishing to Zenodo”.*

Please describe how the provenance of your data can be tracked (e.g., by linking raw and processed data, documenting workflows, and recording software versions and parameters). Consider how other researchers could reproduce your results: is this information documented in your ELN, included in the metadata, or provided as additional accompanying instructions or you have other solutions?

Mention whether you will use electronic lab notebooks (e.g., eLabFTW, Chemotion), institutional systems, or automated workflows (e.g., NOMAD CAMELS capturing instrument metadata). If manual entry is used, describe how you will ensure completeness and consistency.

page.help:
This page describes how you will ensure that your datasets are accurate, reliable, and consistent.
Each dataset should normally be described individually. If identical quality assurance measures apply to several datasets, you may provide one answer and indicate that it covers multiple datasets.

question.help: Describe the procedures you will use to ensure that your datasets are accurate, reliable, and consistent. Typical measures include instrument calibration, use of reference samples, replication of measurements, error analysis, and validation against trusted datasets. For computational work, this may involve convergence testing, cross-code validation, or comparison with experimental results.

section.dc:comment: Storing and archiving research data in a secure and accessible way is crucial for good research practice. In this section, describe your approach to storing and archiving data and metadata, as well as the planned procedures for dealing with sensitive data during the project. This section should deal with the short-term storage and archiving during the project period and completion. The objective is to ensure data accessibility among the project team and external collaborators, and to prevent loss of data due to unforeseen circumstances such as hardware malfunction, theft, or natural disasters.
section.title: Storage and Backup during the Research process

page.title: Data Storage and Access During the Project

page.title: Backup and Data Security
page.help: This page describes how you will protect your data against loss or corruption during the project. Provide information on backup frequency, retention, and verification.

question.help:
Describe how your project data will be backed up during the research phase. Specify:
- **Method:** e.g., institutional backup services, automated mirroring, manual copies, cloud replication.
- **Strategy:** If you apply the 3-2-1 principle (3 copies, 2 media, 1 off-site), describe how it is implemented.
- **Frequency:** e.g., daily incremental, weekly full, monthly snapshots.
- **Retention period:** how long backup copies are kept (e.g., 180 days, 12 months).
Examples: “Daily incremental backups and weekly full backups on the university’s HPC storage system.”; “Automated replication to an off-site facility with 12-month retention.”
question.text: How will data and metadata be backed up during the project?

question.help: Select the security measures that apply to your project. This may include infrastructure safeguards (e.g., firewalls, VPN, encryption), organizational controls (e.g., restricted access, NDAs), and procedures for handling sensitive data. If none of the listed measures apply, choose Other and specify.

page.title: Data Reuse and Sharing
page.help: This page describes how your research data will be shared with the community for reuse. Please indicate which data are suitable for reuse, how and where you will make them available, when they will be released, and under which license. If restrictions apply (e.g., due to industrial collaboration, intellectual property rights, or ethical concerns), please explain them.

question.help:
Describe which datasets from your project are most relevant for reuse and explain who could reuse them (e.g., researchers in your field, industrial partners, educators) and for what purpose (e.g., benchmarking, validation, machine learning, comparison, teaching).
*Example: Processed diffraction patterns and TEM images can be reused by materials scientists for benchmarking new structural models, and by industry partners for quality control. Simulation input files may be reused by computational scientists for validation and training machine-learning models. Raw experimental logs are not disseminated*
question.text: Reuse of datasets generated by the project

question.help: Specify the timing of availability: immediately, upon publication, after a defined embargo (e.g., 6–12 months), or only under restricted access. Embargoes may be justified for intellectual property, patent filing, or industrial collaboration. Accordingly to the DFG Guidelines for Research Data Management, research data should be made available as soon as possible and ideally according to the FAIR principles. The importance of data publication is underscored once again by the Guideline 13 of the Code of Good Scientific Practice. Discipline-specific practices are pointed out here.

section.dc:comment: It is essential to be aware of legal issues and any specific details prior to initiating the research process. Researchers should clearly describe legal issues in the DMP of their research proposal and consult their research institution’s policies and requirements. We note that materials-science data are not so critical in the sense that they do not concern highly-confidential data about people (like patients in medical science). Still, the data must be handled with care.
section.title: Legal Obligations and Conditions

question.help: Examples: GDPR for personal data, different access rights for project members, contractual agreements with partners or industry, copyright or licensing issues, or restrictions on transferring data between countries.
question.text: What are the legal specifics associated with the handling of research data in your project?

question.help:
Explain who holds ownership and how rights are regulated. Mention:
- Institutional vs. industrial ownership. - Planned licenses (e.g., CC BY, CC0, MIT, GPL). - Any embargo for publications or patents.
Example: “Simulation input/output data will be published under CC BY 4.0. Proprietary datasets remain accessible only to partners. All software scripts will be released under the MIT license.”
question.text: How will intellectual property rights (IPR), copyright, and ownership of the generated data be managed?

question.help:
It is possible that there are reasons that can speak against a (direct) publication of the data. This can be, for example, the protection of personal data or the commercial or industrial use of the data. Confidentiality related to security issues can also be a reason. You can find more information in Guideline 13 of the code on Good Scientific Practice.
Please keep in mind that the data can be published after a certain blocking or embargo period and that you can also prepare this publication now.
question.text: Do you anticipate any implications or restrictions regarding subsequent publication or accessibility?

option.text: Yes, parts of the data are subject to non-disclosure agreements (NDAs) and therefore cannot be published at this stage.

This template assumes no processing of personal data; use dedicated guidance/templates where personal data are involved. By selecting “Yes—personal data,” you confirm you are aware of these obligations and have applied appropriate measures.

section.dc:comment: It is important to consider the personnel and physical resources needed to execute and control the described data management strategies, tasks, and tools. Each member or organization participating in the research proposal should be assigned a clear role based on their expertise and time availability. This ensures that everyone knows what is expected of them when dealing with research data.
section.title: Data Management Responsibilities and Resources

page.title: Responsibilities for Research Data Management
page.help:
This page asks you to define who is responsible for handling research data during and after your project. Define who is responsible for research data management (RDM) in your project. This includes both the main contact person and, if relevant, additional roles for specific tasks such as data curation, metadata, backups, PID maintenance, and digital preservation.
*According to the DFG, the PI has the overall responsibility for ensuring good data management. However, dedicated staff or external infrastructures may carry out specific tasks. Research data must be retained for at least 10 years following the DFG Code of Conduct.*

questionset.title: Specific Responsibilities
questionset.help: If there are other project partners who are responsible for subtasks in the RDM in this project, please specify.

question.text: Data curation (e.g. cleaning, quality control, organizing)
Metadata and documentation (e.g. ELN management, metadata accuracy)
Backups and data security (responsible for ensuring data are backed up and access protected)
Persistent Identifiers (PIDs) (responsible for DOI/handle assignment and long-term maintenance)
Digital preservation / archiving (responsible for long-term storage, repository decisions, data migration)

question.help: Examples of this are the allocation of access data/access authorizations, the optimization of storage space after a certain retention period or the transfer of authority to a new contact person. Such decisions are necessary, for example, in the event of a loss of access data, a new access request or the departure of the previous contact person. We recommend to name the head of department or the department itself.
question.text: What persons or institutions can be mentioned as the long-term contact who can decide on the data?

page.title: Resources for Research Data Management
page.help:
This page asks you to specify the resources needed for effective data management. Adequate resources ensure that data can be collected, documented, stored, shared, and preserved in line with FAIR principles and DFG requirements.
Please include:
- Personnel effort: Estimate time for data stewardship, documentation, and repository submission (e.g., in person-months or % FTE).
- Non-personnel resources: Technical infrastructure (servers, storage, software licenses, cloud services) and other costs needed for RDM.
- Training and support: RDM training, FAIR compliance workshops, or professional development activities for staff.
- Infrastructure services: Identify the repositories, archives, or institutional systems that will be used (e.g., NOMAD, Zenodo, university HPC or storage systems).
DFG allows you to request project-specific costs for data preparation, documentation, and deposition if these are not already covered by institutional infrastructure.

question.help: Please estimate the effort in person-months (1 PM = monthly working time of a full-time employee). This includes time spent by researchers, postdocs, PhDs, or data stewards for documentation, processing, and repository submission.
